Award.AwardTitle: Coupled Transport and Reactions in Low-Dimensional Nanofluidic Structures for Enhanced Chemical Measurements
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Paul Bohn and his research group at the University of Notre Dame will seek to exploit new physical phenomena that emerge when chemistry is carried out in nanostructures whose dimensions are less than 100 nanometers. In particular, confining chemical reactions to these small volumes under conditions where the delivery of reactants and the extraction of products is controlled, is expected to yield significant improvements in the sensitivity of molecular sensing and the efficiency of chemical processing. The Bohn group will fabricate nanometer scale reactor vessels using various deposition and lithographic techniques. The reactor structures will allow for both optical and electrical measurements to be made on the chemical systems contained within them.

This project explores a new class of nanostructures in which transport is intimately coupled with reactivity and measurement in zero-dimensional, 0-D, and one-dimensional, 1-D, architectures. Specifically, the experiments enable the coupling of chemical measurements with multiple sequential reactions/manipulations by addressing two broad objectives: (1) the high efficiency coupling of electrokinetic flow to Faradaic electrochemistry in 1-D nanoscale architectures; and (2) the development of high sensitivity (single molecule) spectroelectrochemistry to characterize single electron transfer events in 0-D nanostructures. New nanoscale architectures are being developed that couple electrokinetic flow to heterogeneous electron transfer and access new routes to high sensitivity redox cycling to amplify electrochemical measurements. Additionally, nanostructures are being developed to couple electron transfer events to modulation of light emission, thereby providing access to single electron transfer events in single molecules. The project is coupled to the development of a new type of graduate program in chemical measurement sciences, termed Analytical Sciences and Engineering at Notre Dame (ASEND), that spans disciplines across traditional engineering and natural sciences departments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on understanding how chemical measurements can be extended to ultrasmall physical structures and developed the approaches to control chemical reactions in such structures by addressing two principal topics: (1) the effect of various kinds of field-driven fluid flow on electron transfer reactions at nanoscale solid-liquid interfaces; and (2) combining spectroscopy and electrochemistry to develop new experimental tools to study single molecule electron transfer events in ultrasmall volume nanostructures.

The chief problem in accomplishing electrochemistry in high external fields, such as those required to drive fluid flow electrokinetically, is that the local potentials are well beyond what is required to electrolyze the solvent, thus obscuring information from redox-active molecules in solution. We devised a multi-faceted approach to this problem. First, we developed an optically isolated potentiostat, allowing the reference electrode to float to the local potential of the electrified fluid, making it possible to obtain well-behaved voltammetry at local potentials approaching 1500 V and at field strengths up to 3000 V/cm. In a parallel approach, we used nanopore electrode arrays as the basis for bipolar electrochemical cells. In these cells, electron transfer events of interest at nanoscale electrodes in the analytical cell are coupled to remote reporter reactions, which can be selected to be fluorogenic, plasmonic, or electrochromic depending on the desired sensitivity level. This strategy accomplished two important objectives - physical separation (up to centimeters away) of the analytical and reporter cells and converting  electron transfer measurements from electrical to optical readouts. In addition, by adding a second electrode to these structures it was possible to sequentially cycle reactants back and forth, resulting in enormous increases in sensitivity - up to 1000-fold in the absence of supporting electrolyte. These strategies also enhanced the electrochemical selectivity by up to 3000x, as demonstrated for detection of dopamine in the presence of its predominant electrochemical interference, ascorbic acid. In a second phase of experiments with these structures, we prepared hierarchically-organized nanostructures in which up to 3 annular electrodes separated by a 70-nm gap and 2 permselective membranes were combined to demonstrate electrochemical diode and transistor functions. Furthermore, strong electrochemical rectification was observed by manipulating field-induced gating across a 70-nm silicon nitride dielectric layer on the bottom electrode.

In order to study single molecule electron transfer events in ultrasmall volume nanostructures, we developed a new kind of nanoarchitecture - the electrochemical zero-mode waveguide (E-ZMW) - which traps optical radiation and enables the spectroscopic interrogation of electron transfer events confined to volumes as small as 10-17 liters (see Figure). This allowed us to implement completely new kinds of experiments, such as the fluorescence analogs of static- and active-potential control electrochemical experiments - chronofluorometry, the fluorescence analog of chronoamperometry, and cyclic potential sweep fluorometry, the analog to cyclic voltammetry. These measurements in turn enabled unprecedented observations of the behavior of very small collections of matter - for example, long-lived flavin semiquinone states stabilized in the zeptoliter-volume E-ZMW and correlated electrochemical currents at top and bottom ring electrodes in an array in which only one pore in 1000 was occupied on average.  This was the first observation of correlated electrochemical events in a nanopore array. These, in turn, enabled the first observation of spectroscopic (fluorescence)-electrochemical correlations arising from single molecule population fluctuations on the array. Taken together these results illustrate the potential of the E-ZMW structure to probe coupled electrochemistry and spectroscopy of samples containing one, or a few, molecule(s).

The broader impacts of this project were made by developing programs for teaching and research that span universities and by creating new platforms for industry-university cooperation that can have substantial impact on economic development. The former was demonstrated by the formation of the Indiana Consortium for Analytical Science and Engineering (ICASE). Using ICASE as a platform, we worked to create an ecosystem for the chemical and biomolecular measurement sciences that address the specific needs of Indiana businesses, by providing opportunities for new company start-ups, by licensing technologies developed at the consortium partners to Indiana firms and by making available a highly trained and motivated professional workforce. We also worked to improve the climate for high-technology ventures within Indiana by working closely with public and private groups to make the case for measurement-science-based companies to invest in Indiana.
